concepts.unlisted_description: Woman's separate property under Hindu law, subject to specific succession rules

anchor.surface_text: Paragraph 147 says Stridhana other than shulka passes in the following order  1  unmarried daughter  2  married daughter who is unprovided for  3  married daughter who is provided for  4  daughters daughter  5  daughters son  6  son  7  sons son. If there be none of these, in other words, if the woman dies without leaving any issue, her stridhana, if she was married in an approved form, goes to her husband, and after him, to the husbands heirs in order of their succession to him on failure of the husbands heirs, it goes to her blood relations in preference to the Government.

concepts.interpretation: Exhaustive order: unmarried daughter > married daughters (unprovided/provided) > daughter's daughter > daughter's son > son > son's son; then husband > husband's heirs > blood relations; does not include son's daughter after son's son

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: claim of defendants Nos. 1 to 3 but the High Court held that the plaintiff was exclusively entitled to the suit properties, he being the nearest heir

concepts.unlisted_description: Order of succession to non-shulka stridhana of woman married in approved form as per Mullas para 147

Therefore while pronouncing on the competing claims made in this case, we must be guided by the order of succession prescribed in paragraph 147, if the same is correct and exhaustive.

arguments.claim: Order of succession in para 147 of Mulla is correct and exhaustive

anchor.surface_text: Therefore while pronouncing on the competing claims made in this case, we must be guided by the order of succession prescribed in paragraph 147, if the same is correct and exhaustive.

arguments.claim: Stridhana passes in specific Mitakshara order; children do not take jointly or as tenants-in-common

anchor.surface_text: It is not well settled that stridhana of a Hindu woman governed by Mitakshara passes in the order mentioned in Mitakshara and the children of the deceased woman do not take the same as a body either jointly or as tenants in common.

holdings.text: The order of succession to stridhana other than shulka prescribed in paragraph 147 of Mulla's Principles of Hindu Law is correct and exhaustive

anchor.surface_text: It is the admitted case of the parties that the properties in question are not shulka and that Barji was married in one of the approved forms. Therefore while pronouncing on the competing claims made in this case, we must be guided by the order of succession prescribed in paragraph 147, if the same is correct and exhaustive. Paragraph 147 says Stridhana other than shulka passes in the following order  1  unmarried daughter  2  married daughter who is unprovided for  3  married daughter who is provided for  4  daughters daughter  5  daughters son  6  son  7  sons son.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Admitted not shulka, approved marriage; order up to son's son unchallenged and well settled; rejects challenges to extension or interpretation

holdings.text: The daughters of a pre-deceased son are not entitled to succeed to the stridhana of a Hindu woman married in approved form after failure of heirs up to son's son

anchor.surface_text: Hegde, J. The question of law that arises for decision in these appeals by certificate is whether the daughters of a pre-deceased son of a Hindu Woman are entitled to succeed to her stridhana ? The trial court answered the question in the affirmative but the High Court in appeal came to the conclusion that they are not entitled to succeed to the estate in question.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Para 147 exhaustive order excludes son's daughters after son's son; goes to husband then sapindas; rejects textual expansion, illustrative argument, propinquity, interpretive rules

holdings.text: Colebrooke's translation of Mitakshara accurately reflects the order of succession to stridhana

anchor.surface_text: Mr. A.K. Sen, learned Counsel for some of the defendants contested the correctness of Colebrookes translation in certain respects. He wanted us to examine the original text to find out whether the translation found in placita 9 is correct ? ... Hence we are unable to agree with Mr. Sen that Colebrookes translation does not bring out accurately the meaning of the relevant passages in Mitakshara.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Colebrooke distinguished scholar; relied by Judicial Committee, High Courts; accords with Jogendra Nath Bhattacharya and Justice Chandavarkar

holdings.text: The list of heirs in Mitakshara paragraph 147 is exhaustive, not merely illustrative

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Bishan Narain, learned Counsel for defendants Nos. 1 to 3 contended that the list given in Mitakshra is only illustrative and not exhaustive. ... This contention is opposed to the commentaries by Narada, Gautama and the later commentators. More than that it runs counter to the decisions rendered by the Judicial Committee and the various High Courts during the last over a century.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Opposed to ancient commentaries and over a century of Judicial Committee/High Court decisions; settled law

holdings.text: Stridhana of Hindu woman under Mitakshara passes strictly in the specified order; children do not take jointly or as tenants-in-common as a body

anchor.surface_text: It is now well settled that stridhana of a Hindu woman governed by Mitakshara passes in the order mentioned in Mitakshara and the children of the deceased woman do not take the same as a body either jointly or as tenants in common. Only the heirs belonging to a class take the properties as tenants in common.

holdings.text: Propinquity is not the sole or principal test of succession to stridhana under Mitakshara

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Bishan Narain next contended that under Mitakshara propinquity is the test of inheritance. ... We do not think that in the matter of succession to stridhana propinquity was considered by the law givers as the sole or even the principal test, otherwise there is no justification for a daughters daughter or a daughters son to succeed to the estate of a woman in preference to her son.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Internal inconsistency if applied: daughter's descendants precede son

holdings.text: The expression 'son's son' does not include 'son's daughter'; masculine does not include feminine in this context

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to accept the contention of Mr. Bishan Narain that the expression sons son includes sons daughter as according to the rules of interpretation the masculine includes the feminine. That rule of interpretation is inapplicable in the present case as daughters daughter succeeds to the stridhana in preference to daughters son.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Gendered order (daughter's daughter before daughter's son) precludes interpretive expansion

holdings.text: Hindu Woman's Rights to Property Act, 1937 does not apply to stridhana or property of a Hindu female

anchor.surface_text: Lastly Mr. Sen contended that in view of the Hindu Womans Rights to Property Act XVIII of 1937 , it must be held that defendants 1 to 3 are nearer heirs to the deceased than the plaintiff. ... It does not apply either to the coparcenary property or to the property of a Hindu female.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory scope limited to separate property of intestate Hindu male; confirmed by Annagouda precedent

anchor.surface_text: It is the admitted case of the parties that the properties in question are not shulka and that Barji was married in one of the approved forms. Therefore while pronouncing on the competing claims made in this case, we must be guided by the order of succession prescribed in paragraph 147, if the same is correct and exhaustive. Paragraph 147 says Stridhana other than shulka passes in the following order  1  unmarried daughter  2  married daughter who is unprovided for  3  married daughter who is provided for  4  daughters daughter  5  daughters son  6  son  7  sons son.

anchor.surface_text: Hegde, J. The question of law that arises for decision in these appeals by certificate is whether the daughters of a pre-deceased son of a Hindu Woman are entitled to succeed to her stridhana ? The trial court answered the question in the affirmative but the High Court in appeal came to the conclusion that they are not entitled to succeed to the estate in question.
the High Court held that the plaintiff was exclusively entitled to the suit properties, he being the nearest heir to the deceased.

Mr. A.K. Sen, learned Counsel for some of the defendants contested the correctness of Colebrookes translation in certain respects. He wanted us to examine the original text to find out whether the translation found in placita 9 is correct ? ... Hence we are unable to agree with Mr. Sen that Colebrookes translation does not bring out accurately the meaning of the relevant passages in Mitakshara.
the High Court held that the plaintiff was exclusively entitled to the suit properties, he being the nearest heir to the deceased.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Bishan Narain, learned Counsel for defendants Nos. 1 to 3 contended that the list given in Mitakshra is only illustrative and not exhaustive. ... This contention is opposed to the commentaries by Narada, Gautama and the later commentators. More than that it runs counter to the decisions rendered by the Judicial Committee and the various High Courts during the last over a century.
the High Court held that the plaintiff was exclusively entitled to the suit properties, he being the nearest heir to the deceased.
the High Court held that the plaintiff was exclusively entitled to the suit properties, he being the nearest heir to the deceased.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Bishan Narain next contended that under Mitakshara propinquity is the test of inheritance. ... We do not think that in the matter of succession to stridhana propinquity was considered by the law givers as the sole or even the principal test, otherwise there is no justification for a daughters daughter or a daughters son to succeed to the estate of a woman in preference to her son.
the High Court held that the plaintiff was exclusively entitled to the suit properties, he being the nearest heir to the deceased.

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to accept the contention of Mr. Bishan Narain that the expression sons son includes sons daughter as according to the rules of interpretation the masculine includes the feminine. That rule of interpretation is inapplicable in the present case as daughters daughter succeeds to the stridhana in preference to daughters son.
